Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Robert C. Ferrier of University of Pennsylvania to conduct a research project, entitled "Novel Nanocomposite Conductive Coatings," during the summer of 2012 at Kyoto University in Kyoto. The host scientist is Kohji Ohno.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is, by utilizing novel polymerization techniques, unique electrically conducting, nanocomposite coatings can be realized.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Work at Kyoto University involved the assembly of anisotropic gold particles in polymer thin films. Anisotropic gold particles have shown great promise in a broad range of fields including imaging, cancer treatment, and optically absorbent coatings, among others. The wavelength at which anisotropic gold particles absorb light depends upon their separation distance and orientation. When gold particles come together in an end-to-end fashion they will absorb light at higher wavelengths when compared to gold particles that come together in a side-by-side fashion. Absorbing light at high wavelengths makes anisotropic gold nanoparticles attractive in stealth coatings for aircraft.

Anisotropic gold particles were made at the University of Pennsylvania. The sides of these particles consisted of a polymer and the ends were free to be modified later. At the University of Kyoto, a different polymer was grafted to the ends of the anisotropic gold particles. When the gold particles were then cast in a polymer thin film, they would assemble in an end to end fashion, shifting the absorbance to a higher wavelength. In order to tune this wavelength, polymer was grown from the ends of the anisotropic gold nanoparticle. Growing from the ends of the particle allows for precise control over the length of the polymer. The length of the polymer controls the separation distance of the particles within the film and, therefore, the final absorbance wavelength of the film. The growth process of the polymer was able to be optimized and growth from the surface was successful. This work will be further continued at the University of Pennsylvania where films of these particles will be made and characterized and different lengths of polymer will be grown.
